statement.text: Fasciotomy is a surgical procedure involving incision of the fascia to release elevated pressure within muscle compartments, preventing or treating compartment syndrome. In vascular surgery and trauma, fasciotomy is indicated prophylactically when prolonged ischemia (>4-6 hours) precedes revascularization, and therapeutically when compartment syndrome develops after reperfusion. The lower leg requires four-compartment release through two incisions (medial and lateral), while the forearm requires release of volar and dorsal compartments.
statement.formal: Fasciotomy: Surgical release of fascial compartments to treat or prevent compartment syndrome. Indicated prophylactically with ischemia >4-6 hours, therapeutically with compartment pressures >30 mmHg or Î” <30 mmHg from diastolic pressure.

explanation.intuition: Muscle compartments are like sealed containers - the fascia doesn't stretch. When blood flow is restored after prolonged ischemia, the muscles swell dramatically (reperfusion injury). If the container can't expand, pressure builds inside, crushing the muscles, nerves, and eventually cutting off blood flow again. Fasciotomy is like cutting open the container to allow the swelling tissue room to expand without self-destruction.
explanation.key_insight: The decision for prophylactic fasciotomy is time-based: if ischemia duration exceeds 4-6 hours of warm ischemia before revascularization, reperfusion edema is expected and prophylactic fasciotomy should be performed. Waiting for signs of compartment syndrome after revascularization risks irreversible muscle and nerve damage. The mantra is: 'When in doubt, cut it out.'
explanation.technical_details: Compartment pressure can be measured directly using a needle manometer or Stryker device. Absolute pressure >30 mmHg or delta pressure (diastolic BP minus compartment pressure) <30 mmHg indicates compartment syndrome. Lower leg has four compartments: anterior, lateral, superficial posterior, and deep posterior. The two-incision technique uses a lateral incision over the fibula (anterior and lateral compartments) and a medial incision 2cm posterior to the tibial border (superficial and deep posterior compartments). All four compartments must be released completely. Fasciotomy wounds are left open and managed with negative pressure wound therapy or wet dressings, with delayed primary closure or skin grafting at 3-7 days.

therapeutic: Clinical signs of compartment syndrome (6 Ps)
Pain out of proportion to injury with passive stretch

early: Pain out of proportion to visible injury
Pain with passive stretch of compartment muscles
clinical_signs_compartment_syndrome.important_note: Pulses may be present even with compartment syndrome - do not rely on pulses alone

anterior.contents: Tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, deep peroneal nerve

lateral.contents: Peroneus longus and brevis, superficial peroneal nerve

deep_posterior.contents: Tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, posterior tibial artery/nerve
deep_posterior.access: Medial incision, release soleus off tibia

lateral_incision.location: Midway between tibial crest and fibula
lateral_incision.length: Full length of leg (knee to ankle)

medial_incision.key_step: Must detach soleus from tibia to access deep posterior

key_principles: Incisions must be full length of compartment
All four compartments must be released
Fascia must be incised, not just skin
Apply negative pressure wound therapy or wet-to-dry dressings

wound_management.initial: Leave fasciotomy wounds open, wet dressings or NPWT
wound_management.debridement: Return to OR at 24-48 hours for second look if concern

closure.skin_grafting: If delayed primary closure not possible

timely_fasciotomy.complications: Wound healing, infection, need for skin grafting

definition.@value: Surgical release of fascial compartments to prevent or treat compartment syndrome, indicated prophylactically after prolonged ischemia or therapeutically with elevated compartment pressures

sources.citation: Feliciano DV, Moore EE, West MA. Trauma, 9th Edition. McGraw-Hill Education, 2020.
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 10th Edition, Chapter 88

learning_objectives: Identify indications for prophylactic vs therapeutic fasciotomy
Recognize clinical signs of compartment syndrome
Describe the four compartments of the lower leg and their contents
Perform a two-incision four-compartment fasciotomy technique
Manage fasciotomy wounds and plan for closure
clinical_pearls: Ischemia >4-6 hours = prophylactic fasciotomy at time of revascularization
Pain with passive stretch is the earliest and most reliable sign of compartment syndrome
Pulses may be present with compartment syndrome - do not rely on pulses
'When in doubt, cut it out' - err on side of fasciotomy
All FOUR compartments must be released in the lower leg
Must release soleus off tibia to access deep posterior compartment

medicalCode.description: Division of right lower leg subcutaneous tissue and fascia, open approach
Decompression fasciotomy, leg; anterior and/or lateral compartments only
